stream_context.summary: Kaze iterates on the crab enemy for the koi-fish mission: he abandons an existing crab model due to texture/clarity concerns, builds a new Mario Kart–inspired 3D crab with an N64-friendly poly budget, and defines the animation set needed before implementing the full crab mission. He also debugs koi behavior (a velocity parameter wasn’t being read), discusses enemy spawning/performance costs, and briefly raises concerns about keeping VODs public as potential Nintendo "ammunition."
stream_context.significance_reason: Contains a clear design pivot (scrapping one crab approach for a new 3D enemy), concrete production constraints (triangles/bones/texture formats, culling behavior), a real gameplay AI bug fix for the koi, and a defined handoff to Zeina with a specific animation checklist—useful for documentary timeline and pipeline discussions.

findings.summary: Kaze decides to scrap the current crab implementation/model and instead remake a different, "cooler" Mario Kart-style crab in 3D because the old crab’s texture and silhouette/readability weren’t working and the gameplay interaction (how to defeat it) felt unclear.
findings.quote: Yeah, fuck this crab. We're making a new one.

findings.summary: The crab is tied to a specific mission concept: crabs circle/bother koi fish; defeating the crabs frees the koi; freeing koi yields a Star and possibly a hint toward accessing a secret level.
Kaze strongly prefers 3D enemies over 2D sprites for this hack, framing 2D enemies on N64 as aesthetically/ideologically wrong for a console marketed around 3D.
findings.quote: We marketed this as the 3D console and then we're putting in 2D enemies? Come on.

findings.summary: He targets an N64-appropriate triangle budget for the crab (roughly Goomba-scale complexity), repeatedly optimizing geometry and accepting minor “internal” holes/triangle removals because the enemy will be small onscreen.

Texture workflow becomes a bottleneck: the original crab texture source was "garbage" and forced a retexture; he switches approaches (including using an i8 texture format) and adds simple reflection/highlight treatment to improve shell readability.
findings.quote: I think we have to retexture the crab.

findings.summary: Kaze notes a constraint tradeoff: beyond triangles, bone count is a bigger limiting factor for this actor, and he declines additional features (e.g., extra bones/eye bulge) because the crabs are already pushing the level’s resource limits.

He explains runtime behavior: when a level loads, all enemies spawn at once; many actors reduce cost when offscreen by skipping their main loop; he estimates offscreen cost can be around ~1 microsecond for some enemies.

Koi behavior looked wrong because a key parameter (koi velocity) was never actually being read; after discovering this, he adjusts turning speed/avoidance behavior so the fish properly react to Mario (especially before being “saved”).
findings.quote: The whole time we have not been reading the koi velocity.

findings.summary: Kaze plans to hand the finished crab model off to Zeina for animation, defining a concrete list: walk, idle/look-around, threatening dance/idle, and a defensive curl/unfurl (triggered when Mario jumps on them).

He questions whether leaving stream VODs publicly archived is strategically risky, worrying Nintendo could comb them for "ammunition" (claims that assets are stolen), while also acknowledging that leaving them up signals confidence nothing illegal is happening.
findings.quote: I'm thinking maybe it's tactically not smart of me to upload VODs.

findings.summary: Kaze gives a project progress snapshot: he frames the hack as ~"part 5" of ~13 meaningful worlds/areas (with one being a quick tunnel) and suggests most remaining parts are smaller than the current one (except possibly 14).
He describes ongoing exhaustion and attributes a decline in speaking fluency to years of isolated work, implying the personal cost of building the ROM hack.
findings.quote: Spending four years alone in a room without talking kind of murdered that. But I had the romhack to make, so it was worth it.

zeina.summary: Kaze states Zeina is already making a completely new HUD for the project and that it looks decent so far.
Kaze explicitly assigns Zeina the crab animation workload and specifies the required animation set, making this a clear cross-discipline handoff moment.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: Spending four years alone in a room without talking kind of murdered that. But I had the romhack to make, so it was worth it.
memorable_quotes.context: A rare, personal acknowledgment of isolation and the tradeoff between life and finishing the project—strong interview material about creative cost.

memorable_quotes.speaker: Kaze
memorable_quotes.quote: We marketed this as the 3D console and then we're putting in 2D enemies? Come on.
memorable_quotes.context: Captures his aesthetic/ideological stance on respecting the N64’s identity, which directly drives asset and enemy design choices.

key_stories.title: Scrapping the crab and rebuilding a new 3D enemy for clarity and N64 constraints
key_stories.summary: Kaze starts uncertain about how the crab encounter should work and quickly realizes the existing crab model is both visually and mechanically awkward. He pivots mid-stream to rebuild a new Mario Kart–style crab in 3D, optimizing it for triangle/bone limits while improving texture readability.
key_stories.challenge: The existing crab didn’t read well (bad texture/silhouette) and the interaction design (how players defeat it, how claws/shell should behave) felt unconvincing.
key_stories.process: He evaluates the model against gameplay needs, rejects the old texture pipeline, selects a different Mario Kart crab design as reference, models a new symmetric crab, reduces triangles aggressively, and iterates on textures/reflections and material choices for N64.
key_stories.outcome: A new crab model he’s “extremely happy” with, positioned as the replacement enemy for the mission and scalable for larger variants; next step is animation before final mission scripting.
key_stories.key_quote: Yeah, fuck this crab. We're making a new one.

key_stories.title: The koi fish looked wrong because velocity was never being read
key_stories.summary: While testing koi behavior near Mario, Kaze realizes the tuning changes weren’t taking effect for a simple reason: the koi velocity variable wasn’t being used at all. Fixing that immediately reframes the rest of his AI tuning work (turn rate, avoidance feel, and calmness).
key_stories.challenge: Fish movement felt too slow/incorrect and didn’t respond as expected to parameter changes; avoidance behavior seemed inconsistent.
key_stories.process: He tests close-range interactions, inspects the code path, discovers the koi velocity parameter isn’t read, then adjusts turn speed and base velocity to get a calmer but responsive swim-away behavior.
key_stories.outcome: Koi response becomes noticeably more correct; he believes a prior “stuck” bug is fixed and adds a note about improving bubble visuals that currently pop/disappear abruptly.
key_stories.key_quote: The whole time we have not been reading the koi velocity.

key_stories.title: Animation handoff: defining what Zeina needs to ship next
key_stories.summary: After finishing the crab model to a workable state, Kaze pauses implementation to formalize the animation needs and send the asset to Zeina. The list doubles as a design spec: the crab’s defensive mechanic (jump on shell → curl/unfurl) is now locked to animation requirements.
key_stories.challenge: The mission can’t be finalized without animations that communicate state changes (idle threat, defense mode, emerging) and support the intended player interactions.
key_stories.process: Kaze adjusts model/shadow expectations, writes a numbered animation checklist, and plans delivery of the asset to Zeina; he also notes constraints that limit extra rig features.
key_stories.outcome: Clear next-step pipeline: Zeina animates (walk, idle/look-around, threatening dance, defensive curl/unfurl), enabling Kaze to finish the crab mission logic afterward.

open_questions.topic: Final interaction design for small vs. big crabs (killable, stun-only, or shell-defense states?)
open_questions.context: Kaze floats multiple defeat behaviors (ground pound, jumping on shell to force defense mode, possibly not killable) and also mentions scaling up the crab for a larger “gang” version that can surround koi.
questions: What exact player verb do you want to teach with the crab—jumping on shells, ground pounds, or something else—and why?
How will the small crabs differ mechanically from the scaled-up big crabs (invulnerability windows, damage, crowd behavior, pacing)?
What did you learn from prototyping the earlier crab concept that changed your mind about what feels “Mario 64-correct”?

open_questions.topic: Mission-to-reward loop: freeing koi, earning a Star, and hinting at a secret level
open_questions.context: Kaze describes a loop where defeating crabs frees koi, grants a Star, and makes fish provide a hint to access a secret level, but the exact delivery and gating are not finalized.
questions: How do you want the koi to communicate the secret-level hint—dialogue, animation blocking, camera cues, or environmental changes?
Is the secret-level access meant to be optional discovery for explorers, or a directed progression beat?
What makes this mission feel thematically like 'Yoshi’s Island' rather than just a generic rescue objective?

open_questions.topic: Risk strategy around public VODs and Nintendo scrutiny
open_questions.context: Kaze weighs whether leaving VODs public is tactically unwise because Nintendo could search streams for potential claims, while also noting that leaving them up signals confidence he’s not doing anything illegal.
questions: Have you changed your archiving strategy over time (public VODs, unlisted, edits), and what incidents made you reconsider?
What kinds of assets or workflow moments do you worry Nintendo could misconstrue, even if you believe they’re lawful?
How do you balance transparency with self-protection when your development process is public by default?
